title: Sankey Valley Park Walking and Cycle Route

images.title: andy / Sankey Valley Park
images.caption: This fishing lake is within Sankey Valley Park. This is a view looking due east down one of two spurs that run from the old disused Sankey St.Helens Canal. It looks as if, looking at the historical map of this area, that the canal and spurs (I'm calling them spurs because they look to be sticking out from the side of the canal) where separated by land at some point but they now form one large fishing lake.

images.title: andy / Sankey Valley Park
images.caption: This is a footpath through Sankey Valley Park between St.Helens and Earlestown. This picture was taken at a junction in the footpath (just where the wooden fence ends there is a path off to the right). Not really sure what the brick structure is.

images.title: Al McDougall / Disused Barn, Sankey Valley Park
images.caption: Disused Barn. Right on the border with grid square SJ5889 to the West, are these disused buildings. A large derelict house also lies nearby - otherwise, apart from the park, the area is all new housing estates.

images.title: Al McDougall / St.Helens Canal, Sankey Valley Park, Warrington
images.caption: St.Helens Canal. This is the view looking south from a bridge over the canal in the park. It's a popular spot for fishing, and often attracts swans. The park follows the canal a mile or so in either direction, and to the south joins the trans pennine cycle path.

images.title: David Long / Bradlegh Swing Bridge and the Sankey Valley
images.caption: Bradlegh Swing Bridge and the Sankey Valley The gap through the trees leads to the footbridge over the Sankey Brook, while the canal towpath gives access North and South to the Sankey Valley Linear Park along the line of the Sankey Canal.

images.title: Sue Adair / Swan and cygnets, Sankey Canal
images.caption: Swan and cygnets, Sankey Canal. The Act authorising the Sankey Brook Navigation was passed in 1755. The Canal which was cut subsequently was carrying coal by 1757, making the Sankey Englands First Canal of the Industrial Revolution, built to bring coal down to the growing chemical industries of Liverpool which rapidly expanded and spread back along the line of the Canal to St Helens, Earlestown and Widnes which were small villages until this period. The Sankey can thus be credited with the industrial growth of the region, it was built for Mersey Flats, the sailing craft of the local Rivers. It now forms the heart of the Sankey Valley Park a haven for wildlife and well worth a afternoon stroll or cycle.

images.title: andy / Sankey Viaduct
images.caption: Sankey Viaduct. This is a view over Sankey Valley Park near Earlestown with Sankey Viaduct in the centre of picture. Sankey Brook is in the foreground.

images.title: David Long / The Blackbrook Basin Terminus of the Sankey Canal
images.caption: The Blackbrook Basin Terminus of the Sankey Canal

description: Enjoy a super, waterside cycle or walk in this country park in Warrington. The valley follows the course of Sankey Brook and the now disused Sankey Canal. The park also contains children's play areas, a maze and a lawned area for families. There is also a meadow, mature woodland and a wetland nature reserve with a variety of birdlife. The path along the Sankey Canal continues all the way to St Helens so you could continue your outing for several more miles if you have time. The Trans Pennine Trail also runs past the park so there is another option here. Our circular walk around Warrington takes you along the River Mersey and the Manchester Ship Canal , with a visit to the pretty Paddington Meadows Nature Reserve. The riverside reserve is located close to Sankey Valley Park and includes meadows, grazing cattle and a wildflower meadow.
